title: Beaded Pouch
creator: Southern Oregon Coast Artist
description: A beaded pouch created by an unknown artist in the Southern Oregon Coast. The beadwork on the pouch is made of many different colors and depicts two flowers visited by a butterfly and another nondescript insect, all surrounded by a heart.
subject: Beaded Bags
citation: Southern Oregon Coast artist. Beaded Pouch. ca. 1850, Portland Art Museum, Portland, Oregon, http://www.portlandartmuseum.us/mwebcgi/mweb.exe?request=record;id=33092;type=101#

title: Corn Husk Bag
creator: Unknown
description: A beaded Cornhusk bag made by an unknown Native American artist from Oregon. The bag depicts repeating green conifer trees on one side, and a geometric square design in green, orange, blue, red, pink, and purple on the other.
subject: Bags
citation: Unknown. Corn Husk Bag. ca. 1920s, Hallie Ford Museum of Art, Salem, Oregon, https://willametteart.pastperfectonline.com/webobject/1618F43E-0758-40BB-9500-121802155937

title: Beaded Bag
creator: Wasco Artist
description: A beaded bag created by an unknown Wasco artist. The bag depicts alternating human and horse figures on the top half and geometric designs on the bottom half.
subject: Beaded Bags
citation: Wasco artist. Beaded Bag. ca. 1860, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York City, New York, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/717543

title: Handled Gathering Basket
creator: Umqua Artist
description: A woven basket presumably used to gather goods created by an unknown artist of the Umpqua people. The basket is made of hazel shoots and spruce roots, and the two materials appear as different colors. The basket features no distinctive patterns or representations.
subject: Woven Baskets
citation: Umpqua artist. Handled Gathering Basket. ca. 1900, Portland Art Museum, Portland, Oregon, http://www.portlandartmuseum.us/mwebcgi/mweb.exe?request=record;id=33889;type=101

title: Basket
creator: Calapooia Artist
description: A woven basket created by an unknown artist of the Calapooia (Kalapuya) people. The basket is made of juncus rush and dyed raffia, creating two colors in the basket.
subject: Woven Baskets
citation: Calapooia artist. Basket. ca. 1890/1920, Portland Art Museum, Portland, Oregon, http://www.portlandartmuseum.us/mwebcgi/mweb.exe?request=record;id=34766;type=101

title: Basket
creator: Tillamook Artist
description: A woven basket created by an unknown artist of the Tillamook people. The basket is made of conifer root and features no distinctive patterns or representations.
subject: Woven Baskets
citation: Tillamook artist. Basket. 1900, Portland Art Museum, Portland, Oregon, http://www.portlandartmuseum.us/mwebcgi/mweb.exe?request=record;id=33877;type=101

title: Basket
creator: Grand Ronde Artist
description: A woven basket with lid and handle created by an unknown artist from the Grand Ronde confederation of tribes, either in contemporary Oregon or Washington. The body of the basket has a climbing spiral pattern; the handle is composed of two overlapping braids. The base of the basket is round but the lid is square-sided, with a braided edge.
subject: Woven Baskets
citation: Grande Rhonde artist. Basket. 1920, Hallie Ford Museum of Art, Salem, Oregon, https://willametteart.pastperfectonline.com/webobject/439145FA-3313-418A-AF13-921733871193

title: Dress and belt with awl case
creator: Wasco Artist
description: A two-hide Plateau dress created by an unknown artist of the Wapato people in the inland Northwest. The dress is decorated with beadwork, elk canines, glass beads, cowry shells, and fringe. The dress is worn with a matching belt and awl case.
subject: Dresses
citation: Wasco artist. Dress and belt with awl case. ca. 1870, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York City, New York, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/717542

title: Owl Sculpture
creator: Wapato People
description: A sculpture of an owl made of rock. Created by an unknown Wapato artist from Suvie Island.
subject: Stone Carvings
citation: Wapato People. Owl sculpture. 1830, Oregon Historical Society Museum, Portland, Oregon, https://www.oregonencyclopedia.org/articles/native_american_art_on_sauvie_island/

title: Rock Carvings
creator: Wapato People
description: A photo of rock carvings from wapato people on sauvie island.
subject: Stone Carvings
citation: Wapato People. Rock Carvings. 1830, Oregon Historical Society Museum, Portland, Oregon, https://www.oregonencyclopedia.org/articles/native_american_art_on_sauvie_island/

title: Pendant with figure
creator: Unknown
description: A sculpture made of bone created by an unknown artist in the ancestral Columbia River, either in contemporary Oregon or Washington. The sculpture depicts a figure wearing an intricate headdress and skirt.
subject: Bone Carvings
citation: Ancestral Columbia River Native American. Pendant with figure. 3rd-13th century, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York City, New York, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/717580

title: Figure
creator: Columbia River Artist
description: A bone figure from an unknown artist of the Columbia River region of either Oregon or Washington, dating back to the 18th century. This small sculpture, carved from bone, exemplifies the artistic traditions and materials used by local Indigenous cultures.
subject: Bone Carvings
citation: Columbia River Native American. Bone figure. 18th century, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York City, New York, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/310727

title: Ladle
creator: Chinook Artist
description: An elaborate wooden ladle created by an unknown Chinook artist, used in ceremonial feasts. The ladle features an oval bowl, finely carved rim, and a flat handle adorned with two guardian birds, reflecting the Lower Columbia River style.
subject: Wood Carvings
citation: Chinook Native American. Ladle. ca. 1850, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York City, New York, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/751538

title: Chief Kamiakin
creator: Gustavus Sohon
description: A sketch depicting Cheif Kamiakin drawn by Gustavus Sohon.
subject: Sketches
citation: Gustavus Sohon. Chief Kamiakin. 1855, Oregon Historical Society Research Library, Portland, Oregon, https://www.oregonencyclopedia.org/articles/indian_boarding_school/

title: Women Weaving on Looms
creator: Unknown
description: A photo of women weaving at Chemawa Indian School in Salem, Oregon. The photographer that took the photo is unknown.
subject: Photographs
citation: Unknown. Women Weaving on Looms. 1937, Oregon Historical Society Research Library, Portland, Oregon, https://www.oregonencyclopedia.org/articles/indian_boarding_school/

title: Beaded Harness
creator: Southern Oregon Coast Artist
description: A beaded harness used to attach animals to vehicles, created by an unknown artist from the Southern Oregon Coast. Features alternating geometric designs down each segment of the harness.
subject: Harnesses
citation: Southern Oregon Coast artist. Beaded Harness. ca. 1850, Portland Museum of Art, Portland, Oregon, http://www.portlandartmuseum.us/mwebcgi/mweb.exe?request=record;id=33093;type=101

title: Basket with lid
creator: Unknown
description: A small, tightly twined basket with lid. The basket has bold geometric pattern on sides and top in black and natural colored fiber; the interior is lined so the exterior weave is not visible on the inside of the basket.
subject: Woven Basket
citation: Unknown. Basket. 1900, Hallie Ford Museum of Art, Salem, Oregon, https://willametteart.pastperfectonline.com/webobject/4BBA6EDE-EC2E-4A13-88BE-157475801688

title: Hamper and lid
creator: Unknown
description: A basket of willow sticks created by an unknown Native American artist of contemporary Oregon, woven into a tall egg-like shape. The matching woven lid is attached by a leather thong.
subject: Woven Basket
citation: Unknown. Basket. Ca. 1900, Hallie Ford Museum of Art, Salem, Oregon, https://willametteart.pastperfectonline.com/webobject/FBB55AC5-65FB-4EB6-9F83-993955088741

title: Clatsop Basket
creator: Unknown
description: A large, open basket, created by an unknown Native American artist of contemporary Oregon. The basket is loosely woven with a decorative band below the rim, light natural brown with a few pairs of dark-dyed fibers.
subject: Woven Basket
citation: Unknown. Basket. Ca. 1930, Hallie Ford Museum of Art, Salem, Oregon, https://willametteart.pastperfectonline.com/webobject/243D9DF6-0D7D-4959-9378-057738755841

title: Acorn mush bowl
creator: Unknown
description: A rounded basket created by an unknown Native American artist of contemporary Oregon. The basket is constructed mostly of a red-brown fibrous plant with an inch-wide band of decoration in yellow near the rim.
subject: Woven Basket
citation: Unknown. Basket. Ca. 1900, Hallie Ford Museum of Art, Salem, Oregon, https://willametteart.pastperfectonline.com/webobject/8D5F6007-0395-4C28-891F-309799605939

title: Basket
creator: Unknown
description: A shallow, spiral woven twined basket created by an unknown Native American artist of contemporary Oregon. The basket features no distinctive designs.
subject: Woven Basket
citation: Unknown. Basket. Pre-1900, Hallie Ford Museum of Art, Salem, Oregon, https://willametteart.pastperfectonline.com/webobject/17188AE0-6D14-4B2E-8319-426553005430

title: Berry Bag
creator: Umatilla Artist
description: A bag made out of commercial dyes, buckskin, and cotton by an unknown Umatilla artist. The bag is primarily made of a light purple cotton with one side featuring a portrait of a Native American with a black and light purple checkered pattern surrounding the portrait.
subject: Buckskin Bag
citation: Umatilla artist. Berry Bag. 1920/1940, Portland Museum of Art, Portland, Oregon, http://portlandartmuseum.us/mwebcgi/mweb.exe?request=record;id=37678;type=101

title: Bowcase and Quiver
creator: Nez Perce Artist
description: A bowcase and quiver made by an unknown Nez Perce artist. The pieces are made of otter skin, leather, wool cloth, glass beads, ermine, and silk ribbon. Originating from Idaho, Oregon, or Washington, this set reflects skilled craftsmanship and the material culture of the Nez Perce people.
subject: Bowcase and Quiver
citation: Nez Perce artist. Bowcase and Quiver. ca. 1870, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York City, New York, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/318357

title: Apron
creator: Southern Oregon Coast Artist
description: An apron made out of beargrass, leather, and glass beads made by an unknown Southern Oregon Coast artist. The band at the top features red and blue string and subtle geometric patterns.
subject: Apron
citation: Southern Oregon Coast artist. Apron. ca. 1850, Portland Art Museum, Portland, Oregon, http://www.portlandartmuseum.us/mwebcgi/mweb.exe?request=record;id=33100;type=101
